import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import astropy.io.ascii
import math
%matplotlib inline

## Project 2: Group 4

### Transit Light Curve and Radius Calculation for Exoplanet GJ436b
#### Contributed by: Missie Bleich
## Read in transit data for GJ 436b

source:
tr_data = astropy.io.ascii.read("UID_0057087_PLC_019.tbl.txt")

data = tr_data.to_pandas() # change our data format into dataframe for easy-use 

# take an overvew of the data set we load
data.head() # if you put nothing into the (), you will get the first 5 rows
# take an overview of all the Column

# quick plot to visualize data
f1 = plt.figure(figsize=(7,5))

JD = tr_data['HJD'].data # julian date in days
flux = np.array(tr_data['Relative_Flux'].data) # tranist depth/fraction of light

plt.plot(JD,flux,'ok')

plt.xlabel('HJD', fontsize = 14)
plt.ylabel('Relative Flux', fontsize = 14)
plt.title('GJ436b: Fig 1', fontsize = 16)

ymin = np.amin(flux)
ymax = np.amax(flux)
plt.ylim(ymin - .0005, ymax + .0005)

# Regenerate the plot using the index of the nth point
# for the X-axis. 

PointNumber = [ i for i in range(len(flux)) ]

f2a = plt.figure(figsize=(10,7))
plt.plot( PointNumber, flux, 'ok')
plt.xlabel('Observation number', fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel('Relative brightness', fontsize=14)
plt.ylim(ymin - 0.0005, ymax + 0.0005)
plt.title('GJ436b: Fig 2a', fontsize=16)

t_start = 245
t_end = 360

X_before = PointNumber[:t_start] # from the beginning to t_start
Y_before = flux[:t_start]

X_during = PointNumber[t_start:t_end] # from t_start to t_end\
Y_during = flux[t_start:t_end]

X_after = PointNumber[t_end:] # from t_end to end of data
Y_after = flux[t_end:]

# Make the plot, showing the in-transit data with different
# symbols.
f2b = plt.figure(figsize=(10,7))

plt.plot( X_before, Y_before, 'ok')
plt.plot( X_during, Y_during, 'or')
plt.plot( X_after, Y_after, 'ok')

plt.xlabel('Observation number', fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel('Relative brightness', fontsize=14)

plt.ylim(ymin - 0.0005,ymax + 0.0005)
plt.title('GJ436b: Fig 2b', fontsize=16)

# Make the plot, showing the in-transit data with different
# symbols. We'll also do legends.

avg_before = np.average(Y_before)
avg_during = np.average(Y_during)
avg_after = np.average(Y_after)

# Path in X and Y for lines.

X_lc = (0.0, t_start,
 t_start, t_end,
 t_end, len(JD))

Y_lc = (avg_before, avg_before,
 avg_during, avg_during,
 avg_after, avg_after)

f2c = plt.figure(figsize=(10,7))

# Data points

plt.plot( X_before, Y_before, 'ok', label='Before')
plt.plot( X_during, Y_during, 'ob', label='During')
plt.plot( X_after, Y_after, 'ok', label='After')

# Eclipse model

plt.plot(X_lc, Y_lc, 'red', lw=4, label='Model')

plt.xlabel('Observation number', fontsize=14)
plt.ylabel('Relative brightness', fontsize=14)

plt.ylim(ymin - 0.0005, ymax + 0.0005)
plt.title("GJ436b: Transit Depth Calculation", fontsize=16)
plt.legend(loc=4, fontsize=16)

def get_transit(avg_before, avg_during, avg_after):
    """
    This function takes the average of the before and after values and then 
    subtracts the average during to get the trasit depth.
    """
    transit = (avg_before + avg_after)/2 - avg_during
    
    return transit


t_depth = get_transit(avg_before, avg_during, avg_after)

print('The transit depth is: ', t_depth)

outputs.name: stdout
text: The radius of GJ436b is  0.03223953862525787 solRad based on this data set.

source:
""" 
from slides: 

- (i) period of transit = (radius of star + radius of planet) / semi major axis
- (ii) depth of transit = (radius of planet/ radius of star)^2

so from (i):  radius of planet = period of transit * semi-major axis - Radius of star
and from (ii): radius of planet = sqrt(depth of transit) * Radius of star

from NEA for GJ 436 (star) and GJ436 b (planet):

- stellar host radius (from NEA) = 	0.41684304009899997±0.00756258617250750 (Rsun)
- semi major axis of planet = 0.0291±0.0015 (AU)
- radius of planet = 	4.170±0.168 (R_earth)  ----> we calculate but this is for reference
- mass of planet = 	22.1±2.3 ( earth mass  ----> we calculate but this is for reference
- planet density = 	1.80±0.29 (g/cm^3) -----> we calculatre but this is for reference

"""

from astropy import units as u
import math

R_host = 0.41684304009899997* u.solRad
#print (R_host)
R_planet = math.sqrt(t_depth) * R_host 
print('The radius of GJ436b is ',R_planet, 'based on this data set.')

source:
import pylightcurve as plc

planet = plc.get_planet('gj436b')   ## Use this to get all the data for the star without manually entring everything

time_array = tr_data["HJD"].data


# Calculate Limb-darkening parameters
limb_darkening_coefficients = planet.filter('clear').limb_darkening_coefficients  ## New way to gt the coeffs

flux_array = planet.transit_integrated(time_array, time_format='BJD_TDB', 
                                           exp_time=120, time_stamp = 'mid', filter_name='clear', max_sub_exp_time=1)

#Error for above: PHOENIX models are only computed for solar metallicity stars. Setting stellar_metallicity = 0.
#Fp/Fs estimated using A=0.15, e=1.0 for filter clear.

f3 = plt.figure(figsize=(10,7))

plt.errorbar(tr_data["HJD"], tr_data["Relative_Flux"], tr_data["Relative_Flux_Uncertainty"], ms=5, \
             marker="o", ls="none", label="Data", color="black", alpha=0.3)

plt.plot(time_array, flux_array, 'r-', lw=3, label="Model")
plt.ylim(plt.ylim()[0], plt.ylim()[1])
plt.xlabel('Time [day]', fontsize = 14)
plt.ylabel('Relative Flux', fontsize = 14)
plt.legend(loc=4, fontsize=16)
plt.tight_layout()


plt.title('GJ436b: Best-fit of Transit Photometry', fontsize = 16)
